text: starting in the late 19th century
technological progress really takes off
just about every aspect of our lives is
changing so we have radio we have
television we have the automobile than
the airplane medicine makes great
advances people get clean water vaccines
antibiotics this was really an age where
humanity was advancing more than at any
other time in our history many things
have improved so cars are safer sofas
are more comfortable I have a better
choice of television programs those are
all forms of progress yes but our lives
have not fundamentally changed the same
way they did in the first half of the
20th century it's fair to say that in
this one area computers and
communications the contemporary world
has made big big advances but what we're
trying to do is to run a new industrial
revolution with essentially only one
dynamic sector whereas earlier in the
20th century all the different parts of
the economy we're moving ahead at that
kind of rapid pace I think it's very
likely innovation will return there are
many smart people in the world cut
innovations come bunched together in
clumps and clusters you have faster
periods and slower periods over the last
few decades we've been in one of those
slower period
